prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PH3 Tuning 1, High Frequency Side
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The 266.9 GHz PH3 line is near the high-frequency limit of ALMA Band 6. This science goal places the lower edge of the upper sideband 250 MHz below the line center. This allows us to search for the spectral slope indicative of PH3 across the 4 GHz of the upper sideband. The 250 MHz offset allows spectral overlap with Tuning 2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will use Band 6 to search for the 266.9 GHz PH3 line and the 216.7 GHz H2S line. Radiative transfer modeling of the Uranus atmosphere indicates this is the strongest tropospheric PH3 line at any frequency, and the strongest H2S line reachable with the ALMA receivers (Fig. 1). (Even if ALMA could reach the stronger 168 GHz H2S line, however, we may not have chosen to target it because it is also significantly broader in frequency. This potentially makes it harder to recognize.) We are seeking only to detect these lines and do not need imaging, so we request one of the most compact configurations of the main array in order to maximize the short baselines needed for a total flux measurement. (If these species are detected, a natural follow-on will be to attempt to image Uranus to study their spatial distribution.) Because we are looking for extremely broad lines (>20 GHz wide), spectral resolution is not an issue, but wide frequency coverage is critical. We therefore will use the largest channel spacing possible and all four spectral windows to give us 4 GHz in each of the two sidebands. The sidebands are separated by ~10 GHz. Thermal emission from Uranus is unpolarized, so we will operate in dual polarization mode to maximize sensitivity. Our sensitivity requirements were described in the Science Case.
Given that the lines we wish to detect are wider than even ALMA's instantaneous bandwidth capability, each line will be observed with two frequency setups. We will first tune to one side of the line center and then the other. The presence of a line is revealed by the differing spectral slopes observed in the two frequency regions. As an example, consider the 266.9 GHz PH3 line in Fig. 2, which is near the upper edge of Band 6. Placing the line center near the high-frequency edge of the upper sideband allows us to use both the upper and lower sidebands to determine the slope on the low-frequency side of the line; the 4 GHz bandwidth of each sideband, separated by 10 GHz, gives us a "lever-arm" of ~18 GHz across which to measure a spectral slope. Because of the band edge, we can only use the upper sideband (spanning ~4 GHz) to determine the slope on the high-frequency side. (There is not enough space between the line and the high-frequency edge of Band 6 to place both sidebands there.) The difference between the slopes measured on either side of the line is an indicator of the amount of PH3 present; if both tunings have the same, modest negative slope (the blue curve of Fig. 2), no PH3 is detected. A similar situation exists for the 216.7 GHz H2S line, which is near the low-frequency edge of Band 6. In this case we can measure the slope across ~18 GHz on the high-frequency side of the line (using both sidebands), but only across ~4 GHz on the low side of the line (using the lower sideband). One other detail of the receiver tuning is that we shifted the bandpasses to start 250 MHz below the line center when measuring the high-frequency side of a line, and 250 MHz above the line center when measuring the low-frequency side. This provides 500 MHz of spectral overlap between the two observations of each line to assist in calibration.
Our observations have one "special constraint" as identified in the Proposer's Guide, which is spending >30% of our time being not on source. This high overhead is the result of Uranus being relatively bright, making it an easy target for ALMA. Our proposal is still appropriate for ALMA, however, because no other instrument has the bandwidth and sensitivity to make these scientifically important measurements.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Ice giant planets are a hot-topic in the planetary and exoplanetary communities. Reasons include the recognition that they are fundamentally different from terrestrial and gas giant planets, that they may be the most abundant type of planet, and that they challenge our understanding of planet formation and evolution. We propose to use ~100 minutes of ALMA time (Band 6, ~230 GHz) in a compact configuration to search for PH3 and H2S in Uranus. Neither species as been spectrally identified, but one or both is expected in order to explain centimeter and near-IR measurements. The abundances suggested by those data are detectable by ALMA. The presence of H2S would be indicative of either a non-solar S/N ratio in the planet or as-yet-unidentified chemistry in the deep troposphere. The presence of PH3, which is not in thermal equilibrium at upper tropospheric conditions, would be indicative of unexpectedly vigorous convection. If neither species is detected it suggests that an unidentified source of microwave opacity exists in the upper troposphere. Thus, the detection or non-detection of either species tests models for the composition, chemistry, and dynamics of Uranus' deep atmosphere.
